data.title: 23 power players using TikTok to shape the music industry in 2021, from record labels to creators
data.meta_description: Insider compiled a list of the record labels, artists, marketers, and creators that excel at using TikTok to promote music in 2021.
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

TikTok has become an important tool for discovering and promoting music, both old and new.

Artists, record labels, marketers, and creators are flooding the app with songs.

Here are the 23 industry players that are using TikTok to shape popular music in 2021.

Sign up to get the inside scoop on today’s biggest stories in markets, tech, and business — delivered daily. Read preview

Thanks for signing up! Go to newsletter preferences

By clicking “Sign Up”, you accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. You can opt-out at any time by visiting our Preferences page or by clicking "unsubscribe" at the bottom of the email.

Advertisement

It's been a big year for music on TikTok.

As the number of record labels and artists flooding the app with songs has exploded, TikTok continues to be a watering hole for viral trends, which can provide a boost to up-and-coming artists and established performers alike.

"TikTok is the only thing that really moves the needle when it comes to streaming," Epic Records' head of digital Lisa Kasha said. "Before, you saw direct impact from radio to artists to sales, whereas now it's completely TikTok."

This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

Those shaping the music industry on the app run the gamut from marketers who pay influencers in an effort to spark a music trend, to artists who have used the app to grow their fan bases.

Advertisement

In May, producer Vano 3000 jumped into the spotlight on TikTok after his sample of BadBadNotGood's "Time Moves Slow" became the soundtrack to a meme. Scottish singer Nathan Evans became a star on the app after a sea shanty trend caught fire. And in late 2020, a group of TikTok users developed a musical version of the Pixar film "Ratatouille" that transformed into a full-fledged production.

"With TikTok, a lot of stuff happens organically," said Gaby Fainsilber, head of digital at Crush Music. "A lot of it is just looking at TikTok constantly, and just seeing what kids are doing on there with our artists and how we can help fuel that."

But that doesn't mean artists don't have a plan.

"These days, for every single artist on the label who's putting out a record, we are strategizing how to make the most out of the TikTok platform," RCA Records' SVP of digital marketing Tarek Al-Hamdouni said.

Advertisement

This is Insider's second annual list of the record labels, artists, marketers, and creators using TikTok to shape the music industry. We spoke with dozens of industry sources for this story to identify professionals that excel at using TikTok to promote music.

Here is the full list for 2021 (listed in alphabetical order):

Advertisement

Ari Elkins, TikTok creator

Ari Elkins (TikTok creator)

Ari Elkins is a 21-year-old senior at the University of Michigan who's built a following of over 800,000 fans on TikTok by creating music recommendation videos.

Elkins' high-energy posts often direct viewers to listen to songs on Spotify, where he has 37 public playlists and about 160,000 followers. His influence on TikTok's music culture, highlighted in a recent Rolling Stone story on the future of music journalism, has since caught the attention of music marketers and festivals that are working with the creator to promote songs and events.

"My life goal currently is to kind of be this Gen-Z music curator," Elkins told Insider. "Ten years ago you had 'TRL' with Carson Daly where kids my age would tune in. Now your options for new music are Spotify playlists that Spotify created or tuning into TikTok."

Advertisement

Carlos A. Cuadros and Tarek Al-Hamdouni, RCA Records

Carlos A. Cuadros (director, digital marketing) and Tarek Al-Hamdouni (SVP, digital marketing)

RCA Records, a label under the umbrella of Sony Music Entertainment, works with a large roster of artists across genres, from Doja Cat and Alicia Keys to Kings of Leon and H.E.R.

The company's 14-member digital marketing team knows firsthand the power of TikTok as a promotional tool, with performers like Doja Cat regularly driving music trends on the app.

Tarek Al-Hamdouni oversees the team, which focuses on online activations, album rollouts, and supporting artists on digital content creation.

Carlos A. Cuadros, who works on Al-Hamdouni's team as director of digital marketing, works on digital strategy with artists like Doja Cat, SZA, Khalid, Alicia Keys, H.E.R., and Jazmine Sullivan, among others. He said the group regularly works with TikTok's music team to understand the best way to promote tracks on the app, whether through livestreamed events, in-app promotions on the sound page, or influencer-marketing campaigns.

"What we've seen lately is that it's becoming far more common where an unreleased song gets teased on TikTok by the artist," Cuadros said. "This gives us the ability to really jump in early on, get fan reaction, [and] see what the influencer reaction is like."

Advertisement

Cesar Toirac, Warner Latina

Cesar Toirac (associate director of marketing services)

Cesar Toirac is a associate director of marketing services for Warner Latina, a Latin music-focused label within Warner Music Group.

Toirac works on social-media strategies for artists like Justin Quiles, Lenny Tavarez, Sofia Reyes, and Zion & Lennox, helping artists build an audience on TikTok by posting and engaging with user videos.

"I spend a lot of time in my little studio apartment listening to music all day and trying to come up with creative ways on how we can sell a song on TikTok," he said.

Toirac recently worked on the label's influencer strategy to promote Justin Quiles' track "Loco" on TikTok via a dance challenge. He also partnered with TikTok's music team in Latin America to feature Warner Latina's artists in a recent livestreamed concert on the app.

Before joining Warner, Toirac worked at Facebook and Instagram as a sales manager for record label brands and streaming services. Prior to Facebook, he worked on streaming analytics at Universal Music Group Latin America.

Advertisement

Chelsea Smith, Warner Music Group

Chelsea Smith (digital accounts manager)

Chelsea Smith is a digital accounts manager at Warner Music Group, serving as a liaison between digital platform partners like TikTok and the various record labels within Warner.

"At each label there's a digital marketing team and their focus is pushing content for their roster," Smith said. "They come to us saying, 'We have this new Cardi B, Lizzo track coming out, how do we optimize it on TikTok?'"

Smith, who works on TikTok strategies under the direction of Warner digital VP Jeff Stevenson, said campaigns on TikTok are often reactive. The team, for example, worked with Canadian rock band Simple Plan after the group's 2002 track "I'm Just A Kid" resurfaced as a meme on the app. Simple Plan later created their own version of the trend on their TikTok account.

"We know everything goes viral on TikTok, and it's hard to make things go viral on your own," Smith said. "If you see something bubbling up, you have to jump on it then because we see TikTok has a direct impact on DSPs (digital streaming platforms) like Spotify, Apple, and YouTube."

Prior to joining Warner Music Group, Smith worked at Universal Music Group in the streaming department at Verve Label Group.

Advertisement

Ethan Geltzer, Arista Records

Ethan Geltzer (VP, digital marketing)

Ethan Geltzer leads the digital marketing team at Arista Records, a label within Sony Music Entertainment.

The company's roster includes a variety of artists who have had breakout hits on TikTok and other social-media platforms, including Tai Verdes, Yung Bae, Carolesdaughter, and Cody Ko and Noel Miller's Tiny Meat Gang.

Arista Records works with its artists to create organic content on the app, while also hiring influencers to boost tracks when it's relevant.

One of its artists, Tai Verdes, rose to fame on TikTok after his singles "Stuck in the Middle" and "A-O-K" took off on the app. Another Arista performer, Yung Bae, went viral last year after the track "Bad Boy" became a meme.

"Digital marketing is very reactive," Geltzer said. "It's all about social listening and recognizing those opportunities, and then amplifying it."

Advertisement

Freddie Morris, 300 Entertainment

Freddie Morris (senior digital director)

Freddie Morris is the senior digital director at record label 300 Entertainment, where he works on digital and social-media strategies for a roster of artists that includes Maria Becerra, Gunna, Waterpark, Young Thug, and $NOT.

Morris told Insider that he's been worked on TikTok since its early days in the US, promoting Maroon 5 and Kendrick Lamar's "Don't Wanna Know" back when the app was called Musical.ly.

The team now uses TikTok to pre-release tracks for 300 Entertainment artists and to help emerging artists build a fan base.

"Our goal for an up-an-coming artist is not necessarily making a song trend but increasing the follower count," he said.

Advertisement

Gaby Fainsilber, Crush Music

Gaby Fainsilber (head of digital)

Gaby Fainsilber is head of digital at Crush Music, a musician management company that works with artists like Sia, Lorde, Green Day, Fall Out Boy, Train, Weezer, Alanis Morissette, and Panic! At The Disco.

Fainsilber has been running the company's digital strategy and marketing since 2008, long before TikTok.

"With TikTok, a lot of stuff happens organically," Fainsilber said. "A lot of it is just looking at TikTok constantly, and just seeing what kids are doing on there with our artists and how we can help fuel that."

One recent viral hit for the company was the resurgence of Sia's 2017 track "Snowman," which entered into the global top ten on Spotify in December 2020 due to a TikTok challenge that had users singing the song in one breath. Sia later posted a video of herself attempting the challenge.

TikTok, Fainsilber said, has been an effective tool for artists like Regina Spektor or Weezer, who have been making music for more than a decade, to get discovered by a new audience.

"It's a whole set of new fans and new generation of people to potentially get eyeballs from and hear their music," she said. "Catalog is super important as well. It's not something we shy away from."

Advertisement

Haley Spencer, Warner Records

Haley Spencer (associate director, fan engagement and digital marketing)

Haley Spencer oversees the digital strategies of about 20 artists at Warner Records, focusing on content rollouts, fan engagement, and media partnerships.

Founded in 1958, Warner Records, a division of Warner Music Group, works with artists across a wide range of genres from long-time performers like David Byrne and the Goo Goo Dolls to TikTok natives like Bella Poarch.

Spencer's team worked with Poarch to promote her debut single "Build A Bitch" on TikTok, uploading a 15-second teaser version of the song on her account two weeks prior to its official release that drove 136 million views and over 14 million "likes."

The team also works with artists to help them take advantage of viral moments that happen organically on TikTok. When Lukas Graham's 2015 track "Mama Said" began trending on TikTok, Spencer worked with Graham to join in on the trend.

"About half of my artists are on TikTok," Spencer told Insider. "Especially during the pandemic, it's pretty much been the main way the label tries to launch a new song or artist."

Advertisement

Jahan Karimaghayi, Benchmob

Jahan Karimaghayi (founder)

Founded in 2015 by Jahan Karimaghayi, Benchmob works on digital and creative strategies for artists, management teams, and brands. The company started off helping artists with social media, but has since expanded into other areas of digital marketing, including working with talent on brand campaigns.

Its client list includes artists like Porter Robinson, Luke Hemmings, Salem Ilese, and Yung Gravy.

Salem Ilese's "Mad At Disney" was one of the breakout hits on TikTok last year, appearing in over 2.5 million videos on the app.

"Our goal with TikTok is not to do the Jason Derulo, Will Smith-style where they have a big production team and you can tell," Karimaghayi said. "We help [artists] learn new filters, learn a new trend, and kind of learn the app."

Advertisement

Jason White, Sarah DeFilippis, and Ciel VanderVeen, MTV Entertainment Group

Jason White (chief marketing officer), Sarah DeFilippis (SVP, digital events, brand and operations), and Ciel VanderVeen (VP, events social & digital)

MTV Entertainment Group, a division of ViacomCBS that includes MTV, VH1, CMT, and a slew of other media brands, has long been a hub for music discovery.

From awards shows like the Video Music Awards (VMAs) to original programming around artists and music videos like "Total Request Live," the company helped introduce Gen-Xers and millennials to new artists and songs.

Now, to reach the next generation of fans, the company is investing heavily in its work on TikTok.

This year, as part of MTV's VMAs, the company's events team partnered with TikTok to create a separate "Trending" category that awarded creators on the app for their work making original dances, audio mash ups, and collaborative videos with artists. During the two weeks around the promotion, which included asking users to vote for winners on TikTok and tune into a VMA livestream on MTV's account, the company said it gained 1.5 million new TikTok fans.

"[TikTok] is clearly the platform of today, especially if you're talking to an audience that's under 30," MTV Entertainment Group's CMO Jason White told Insider. "As a business that recognizes and honors incredible achievements in music, in dance, in choreography, we wanted to make sure that we weren't overlooking this incredible and emerging and established space."

Advertisement

Jeremy O. Harris, Michael Breslin, Patrick Foley, and others, "Ratatouille: The TikTok Musical"

Jeremy O. Harris (executive producer), Michael Breslin (executive producer), Patrick Foley (executive producer), Daniel Mertzlufft (music supervision, arrangement), Ellenore Scott (choreographer), Lucy Moss (director), among others

One of the unexpected projects to emerge from TikTok last year was a musical version of the Pixar film "Ratatouille" conceived by a group of the app's creators.

What started as a short song about the film's rat protagonist made by TikToker Emily Jacobsen became a full-fledged charity performance produced by theater company Seaview and featuring actors like Ashley Park, Wayne Brady, and Tituss Burgess.

Many of the original ideas for the show, which raised over $2 million for The Actors Fund, came from TikTok users who were dueting each other's videos on the app. The videos ended up on the radar of the team at Seaview and of Broadway insiders like Jeremy O. Harris and Ellenore Scott, who helped turn the TikTok trend into a livestreamed performance.

"Working on Ratatouille was such an amazing experience only because of how the steps went to get to the final product," Scott told Insider. "So many things blow up on TikTok that might not have otherwise blown up unless someone made a video about it."

Advertisement

Jun Park, Austin Georgas, and Luis J Najera Jr., Flighthouse

Austin Georgas (senior account manager, music marketing), Jun Park (senior associate, music marketing), and Luis J Najera Jr. (creative strategy lead, music marketing)

Flighthouse is a TikTok-native media company with around 28 million followers. The company built a large following on the app by posting short video skits featuring some of its top stars.

A division of the music-technology company Create Music Group, Flighthouse also works with artists and record labels to promote songs via influencer-marketing campaigns on TikTok.

Recently, the company worked on promotions for tracks like Sam Smith's "Like I Can," Lil Nas X's "Montero (Call Me by Your Name)," DJ Snake's "You Are My High," and the Bee Gees' "More Than A Woman."

"TikTok is where music is being broken, especially for Gen Z," Georgas told Insider in an interview earlier this year.

Advertisement

Lil Nas X, music artist and TikTok creator

Lil Nas X first rose to fame on TikTok following the viral success of his track "Old Town Road."

Now with over 24 million fans, the 22-year-old artist has continued to be a force on the app, solidifying his place among its top artists.

Lil Nas X keeps close tabs on trends on TikTok and across social media generally, reposting or dueting videos that he sees are gaining traction.

Last year, he flooded TikTok with videos to promote his song "Holiday." It's since appeared in over 1 million user videos. Tracks from the artist's 2021 album "Montero" have similarly gone viral on TikTok, with "Montero (Call Me By Your Name)" showing up across 2.3 million posts.

Advertisement

Lisa Kasha, Epic Records

Lisa Kasha (head of digital)

Lisa Kasha is the head of digital at Epic Records, a label within Sony Music Entertainment that works with artists like Travis Scott, Camila Cabello, DJ Khaled, and Meghan Trainor, as well as talent discovered on social media like Madison Beer, Mimi Webb, and music producer Tiagz.

Kasha oversees a team of six staffers that focuses on Epic's digital strategy, including planning song and album promotions on TikTok.

Last year, the group used TikTok to drive streams of "Out West," a collaboration between JACKBOYS, Travis Scott, and Young Thug. The track has since been used in over 11 million videos on TikTok. And in March, the Epic team worked with TikTok on a virtual live concert event featuring Madison Beer.

"We work TikTok from the ground up, whether it's starting a trend on TikTok, or monitoring TikTok and seeing what's happening and doubling down on a trend," she said.

Advertisement

Lizzo, music artist and TikTok creator

Singer, rapper, songwriter, and flutist Lizzo first posted on TikTok in June of 2019, shortly after the release of her album "Cuz I Love You."

But she didn't hit her stride on the app until early 2020 when she started joining in on TikTok trends like the "Renegade" dance and creating her own trends. The 33-year-old artist has since built an audience of 18.9 million fans, one of the largest among music performers on TikTok.

Lizzo often posts videos that aren't directly related to music, like vegan cooking recipes, highlighting how the app can be used by performers when they're not actively promoting an album or song release.

Lizzo's recent single, "Rumors" with Cardi B, became an instant TikTok meme, which the creator immediately jumped on.

Advertisement

Mekaila Morris, Interscope Records

Mekaila Morris (influencer and content marketing manager)

Mekaila Morris is an influencer and content marketing manager at Interscope Records where she works on marketing campaigns on TikTok for pop artists like Billie Eilish and Olivia Rodrigo.

Morris helps artists at Interscope consider which snippets of a song to include on TikTok and works with influencers to promote new tracks on the app. She also helps coordinate promotional gifting to TikTok creators, sending VIP packages to Olivia Rodrigo fans, for example.

Prior to joining Interscope, Morris worked as a creative strategy lead at the media company Flighthouse, where she closely studied what makes a song go viral on TikTok.

"I used to listen to the same part of a song for hours," she said. "Whenever I listen to all of our different artists' projects, that's the lens I look through."

Advertisement

Mike Greene, Alternative Distribution Alliance (ADA)

Mike Greene (VP, integrated digital strategy and commerce)

Alternative Distribution Alliance is a division within Warner Music Group that works with independent artists and labels on their distribution, marketing, and business development efforts.

Mike Greene heads up integrated digital strategy and commerce at ADA, a team that, in addition to other digital work, helps artists get attention on TikTok.

The group recently worked with HitCo on the release of Dixie D'Amelio's single "Fuck Boy," which included a teaser campaign on TikTok and a widely viewed livestream by D'Amelio about the song's lyrics.

Greene said his team looks at data on how songs are gaining traction on TikTok in order to better understand how artists can get involved.

"Is there a trend or movement that we can stick on to?" he said. "Getting artists to participate in whatever that might be and engaging with the community. And then also tapping into things like creator partnerships and influencers to help drive additional reach and discovery on the back of their communities."

Advertisement

Olivia Rudensky, Fanmade

Olivia Rudensky (founder and CEO)

Olivia Rudensky recently founded Fanmade, a digital marketing and fan engagement upstart that works with clients like Miley Cyrus and Hailey Bieber.

Prior to starting her own business, Rudensky worked on campaigns for Cyrus and Lil Nas X at Rebel Management where she helped spearhead the "If Miley Comments" TikTok campaign, a trend where the singer would comment on user videos to drive up engagement on the app. To promote Cyrus' track "Midnight Sky," Rudensky and her team sent a "Midnight Sky" truck to various TikTok influencers, including Addison Rae and Jojo Siwa.

Rudensky first developed a partnership with Cyrus as a child, creating a Miley Cyrus fan account on Twitter at the age of 12. After keeping in touch over the years, she eventually dropped out of college to work with Cyrus on digital strategy full time.

"My role really evolved into more of a marketing person and coming up with the rollout plans," she said. "A lot of it involves TikTok."

Advertisement

Sanu Hariharan, Rebecca Versteegh, and Laurel Cass, Creed Media

Rebecca Versteegh (head of music partnerships), Sanu Hariharan (client direct, music partnerships), Laurel Cass (campaign manager)

Founded in 2018 by Timothy Collins, Hugo Leprince, and Eliot Robinson, Creed Media is a marketing agency based in Stockholm, Sweden.

The team, which now has over 55 employees and recently courted investment from Andrea Radrizzani's Aser Ventures, works with record labels and influencers to promote tracks on TikTok such as Masked Wolf's "Astronaut In The Ocean," Tïesto's "The Business," Trevor Daniel's "Falling," Surf Mesa's "ILY," and Camila Cabello's "My Oh My."

The company helped "Astronaut In The Ocean" go viral on TikTok earlier this year, appearing in over 8 million videos and as a meme in countless other posts.

Rebecca Versteegh leads the music partnerships department at Creed Media, overseeing its work with artists and record labels on marketing campaigns. Sanu Hariharan joined the music industry at the age of 17, working his way up from intern to client director at Creed in two years. Laurel Cass serves as a campaign manager at Creed, where she has worked on hundreds of campaigns and projects, according to the company.

Advertisement

Suzy Yoder, Elektra Music Group

Suzy Yoder (head of digital marketing)

Suzy Yoder is head of digital marketing at Elektra Music Group, a division of Warner Music Group that includes Elektra Records, Black Cement, Public Consumption, DTA Records, Fueled By Ramen, Roadrunner, and Low Country Sound.

Yoder oversees a team of eight staffers who focus on social-media strategies, label and artist website development, email and text marketing, and digital advertising. Her team supports the TikTok strategies of artists across the label, including performers like Tones and I, whose song "Dance Monkey" has appeared in millions of videos on the app. The group also works with social-media star Jxdn (Jaden Hossler), a 20-year-old creator who built a music career after building a fan base on TikTok.

"We've got a lot of developing artists that have found basically what their core fan base is now through engaging on TikTok as a platform," Yoder said.

Yoder began her career at Republic Records, working with artists like Ariana Grande, Zac Brown Band, and Of Monsters And Men, before moving to Girlilla Marketing, and then Elektra starting in 2017.

Advertisement

TikTok's internal music team

It's difficult to consider TikTok's impact on the music industry without recognizing the work of its internal music team.

TikTok has a series of promotional levers, like in-app banners, live video concerts, and playlisting, that it can use to influence how artists get discovered on the app.

The company works closely with artists and record labels to understand their goals on TikTok, and its music operations team can help curate playlists and songs that are promoted to the app's users.

"We have dedicated points of contact for all of the labels, and we work very closely with them to understand what their priorities are," Corey Sheridan, TikTok's head of music operations in the US, told Insider in an interview last year.

Advertisement

Zach Elgort, Atlantic Records

Zach Elgort (manager of digital marketing at Atlantic Records and Big Beat Records)

Zach Elgort manages digital marketing at Atlantic Records and Big Beat Records, an electronic music label within Atlantic.

Elgort focuses on digital strategy for the company's dance and electronic music talent, including artists like Tiësto, Skrillex, Galantis, and Joel Corry. He recently worked on TikTok campaigns for Tiësto's "The Business" and Joel Corry's and MNEK's "Head & Heart," working with creators and media pages to drive millions of views on videos featuring the two tracks.

"With dance and electronic music, it's such a live-music format first," Elgort said. "Figuring out compelling ways to get that music into content that still resonates with an audience is kind of what we're constantly testing and figuring out."

Advertisement

Zach Friedman, Tony Talamo, and Chris Corallo, Homemade Projects

Zach Friedman (cofounder), Tony Talamo (cofounder), and Chris Corallo (head of digital marketing)

Homemade Projects is a management company and upstart record label that works with influencers and music artists on digital strategy, touring, and merchandising.

The company represents social-media star Larri "Larray" Merritt, whose diss track "Canceled" went viral on TikTok last year. Homemade Projects also works on digital campaigns for the label 10K Projects, which is an investor in the company.

As influencer marketers, cofounders Zach Friedman and Tony Talamo, alongside digital marketing lead Chris Corallo, helped promote Trippie Redd's songs "Miss The Rage" and "Holy Smokes," and Internet Money's "His & Hers" on TikTok. The company also worked on campaigns for Salem Ilese's "Mad at Disney" and Peach Tree Rascals's "Mariposa," both of which went viral on the app.
